metadata.title: The preparation and performance of Au loads TiO2 nanomaterials

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Even since industrial revolution in 1760s, the fast development of science and technology has provided powerful impetus to the industrial development process [1, 2]. However, the over exploitation accompanied by the process of human industrialization unavoidably created environmental crisis. It is an urgent task to explore nonpolluting environmental remediation technologies and the substituted of clean power supplements. Solar energy is one of themost abundant natural resources, which could fulfil the energy demand of human beings if utilized effectively. Semiconductor photocatalysis, inwhich the solar energy is used to drive thermodynamic uphill reaction to generate highly energetic chemical fuels or remove inorganic and organic pollutants from the environment, is one of themost important approaches of utilizing solar power directly [3–7].
The history of photocatalysis was date from the 1920s [8–10]. Since Fujishima andHonda discoveredwater photolysis on a TiO2 electrode in 1972, enormous efforts have been devoted to the research of TiO2materials, which has led tomany promising applications in areas ranging fromphotovoltaics and photocatalysis to photoelectrochromics and sensors [11]. Titaniumdioxide (TiO2) is well known to be themost practical and prevalent photocatalyst, as it is chemically stable, abundant, nontoxic, and cost-effective. Plentiful research has been carried out onTiO2 as photocatalyst to enhance the efficiency, and expanding the range of applications [12–17]. Photocatalytic reactions are redox reaction of the semiconductormaterial with the environment which require certain energy equal to or higher than the semiconductor band gap (>3.0 eV for TiO2) [18–20]. The catalytic efficiency is determined by a competition between the charge transfer to the surface of the photocatalyst (for reaction) and recombination [21–28]. For amore efficient utilization of solar light energy, the TiO2 has been
© 2019 IOPPublishing Ltd
investigated formany years, through attempts to increase the sensitivity of TiO2 to visible light: such as dye sensitization and dopingwith suitable impurities. At present, variousmodificationmethodswas still being researched.Wang’s group reported a three-dimensional titaniumdioxide tube-in-tube superstructures (TTS) [29]whileOthmanNWenhanced photocatalytic activity of titaniumdioxide via incorporation of iron (III) carboxylate [30]. In addition, Da Silva preparedmixed-phase TiO2 nanostructures with high photoactive [31]. Preciousmetal based catalysts with excellent stability and unique electrical properties has become the subject of decontamination, despite their high cost. Gold (Au) is one of themost stable preciousmetals,making it attractive for catalyst application and energy storage [32]. In any case, composite semiconductormaterials basically obtained throughmulti-step experimentmethod via tedious process [33].
Nanomaterials possessed abundant surface structure,multitudinousmorphologies, and simple devices, all of whichwere properties in favor of photocatalysis. Therefore, thereweremany research in catalysis domain and in guiding the development of variousmaterials since theywere proposed.Moreover, significant progress in semiconductormaterials has appeared [34–38]. A number of researches focused onthemorphologies and structural in TiO2 to boost photocatalytic performance and extend application [39–41]. For example, nanorods or nanotubes, can provide unique electronic properties, such as high electronmobility or quantum confinement effects, a very high specific surface area, and even show a very highmechanical strength [42]. Synthesis of 1D TiO2 nanostructuresmay achieved by various routes including sol–gelmethods, template-assistedmethods, hydro/solvothermal approaches, and by electrochemicalmeans. Theoretically, electronmoves axially in 1D nanostructures andwas constrained laterally [43, 44]. On the basis of the theory, the approach how boost the separation of electron holes and effective utilization of nucleus are posed. Recently, Nano-assembly revealed a crucial aspect of nanotechnology [45–47]. 1Dheterogeneous nanostructures have received significant progress due to their synergistic effects on photocatalytic properties [48]. Successful examples was reported by Jang’s group andKenanakis’s team [49, 50].Moreover, it was feasible to design the crystal surfacewhich plays primary roles in catalysis to enhance the catalytic activity. LikeWu’s group [51] on facet of TiO2 and Liu ‘s group designed facet of Zn2GeO4 [52, 53].
The nanoscale of particles size was critical factor to its performance. Generally, the reduction of particle size brought the increasing of specific surface area and reaction sites [54]. Nevertheless, there was not amodel to directly express the relationship between particle size and catalytic efficiency. In case of nanoparticles sizewas matched in average free path of electrons, the composite probability of photoelectric electron-hole pair would increase with strong quantum confinement effect. That wasmore possibly if particle was spherical. Therefore, electron utilizationwas closely related to nano-structured and surfacemorphology [55]. But beyond that, the interaction between pollutants and catalysts was also essential element influencing catalysis.
Similar to particle size, it is not a linear correlation. After discussing the reaction rate of different concentrations of thematerials prepared in this experiment, the suitable degradation concentration for different dyes was obtained.
Prof. Zhang had reported synthesizing poly amide network polymer (HBP-NH2)which possess enormous active ammonia ions. Not only as reductant, theHBP-NH2network structures would control themorphology of the nanomaterials [56].
In this paper, goldmodified titaniumdioxidewith nano-meter was prepared through the sol-hydrothermalgelmethod. The amount of Au nanoparticles displayed in catalysis was test.Moreover, the influences of morphology of TiO2 and dye initial concentrationwere also tested in this work.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text: 2.1.Materials Tetrabutyl titanate (TBT,Meryer) andGold (III) chloride solution (HAuCl4, EnergyChemical)were used as precursor. Reagents were of analytical purity without any processing. Other reagents covered ethylic acid (Sinopharm), ethanol (Sinopharm), hydrochloric acid (Sinopharm), sodiumhydroxide (Sinopharm). Methylene blue (Adamas), Rhodamine B (Adamas), Azophloxine (AccuStandard). Branched polyamide polymer (HBP-NH2)was synthesized through Prof. Zhang’smethod [56], and thinning to 100 g l −1 for studies.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation for TiO2NPS
sections.text:
TBT (10 g) and ethanol solutionweremixedwith alcohol solution of acetic acid. The adding process sustained 90 minwith stirring constantly to ensure hydrolysis product of TBTdistribute well inmulticomponent sol. Then, sol converted into gel substance after lay out at room temperature for 24 h.
10 g of the gel was dissolvedwithHBP-NH2 until the solution become clear. Then, themixed solutionwas carried out at 200 °C for 8 h by hydrothermal reaction. The high temperature and pressure reaction conditions
were provided by the polytetrafluoroethylene reactor. At the end of hydrothermal course, unreacted polymer ions on the surface of reactants were wiped off through ethanol and deionizedwater for several times. Finally, samples were drying in hot air oven and for further testing.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Preparation for AuNPS@TiO2NPS
sections.text: In the synthesis of nano-titaniumdioxide catalyst, TBTprocessed a temperate hydrolysis reaction. Thus, TBT was selected as the Ti source, andAuwas fromHAuCl4. The gelmaterial as prepared in the pure TiO2NPS step was addedwithHAuCl4 (0.05 M) before placed into a heated oven. The reactant was executed at 200 °C for 8 h. After purifying andwashing, the AuNPS@TiO2NPS composited particles were successfully obtained. Themass ratios of Au3+ andTi4+were adjusted to 5%, 2%, 1% and 0.5%.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Preparation of AuNPS@TiO2NWS
sections.text: TheAuNPS@TiO2NWS samples was conventional synthesis as our previous work [57]. Here, a brief introduction was as follows. TBT and ethanolmixed firstly and then dropped into tertiarymixture of deionizedwater, ethanol and ethylic acid. Solutionwere stirred for 2 h then formed gels at ambient temperature. Gels turn into nano wires byway of hydrothermal reaction, ion exchange and drying process.

sections.heading: 2.3. Catalyst characterization
sections.text: The surfacemorphology of samples were tested on Field EmissionMicroscope Scanning ElectronMicroscopy (FESEM,Hitachi S-4800, Japan). In order to clearly observe the surfacemorphology of nanomaterials, Transmission ElectronMicroscopy (TEM)was taken onTecnai G20microscope (FEI Company,USA) operated at 200 kV. The crystal formof all sample was conducted through x-rayDiffraction (XRD) (Philips, Holland). The x-ray scan rangewas of 2θ between 20° and 80° at step length of 16 °min−1. The totalMethylene blue concentration in experiment wasmeasured byCary 50BioUV–visible spectrophotometer (Varian,USA) referred 665 nmas characteristic peak. Samemethodwas used for photocatalysis test of Rhodamine B (554 nm) andAzophloxine (532 nm).

sections.heading: 2.4. Test of catalysts activity
sections.text:
Photocatalytic testmethodswere similar, therefore we chose a commonway [58]. Normally, 100 mg catalysts was set in quartz flaskwith 50 ml dye. Then ultrasonicated it to gain a homogeneousmixture. TheUV-light (20W) as light source runs through all catalysts experiment. Before theUV exposure, suspensionwas stirred in dark room for 30 min to achieve adsorption equilibrium [58]. The photocatalytic test timewas 5 h and the height between light source and liquid surfacemaintained at 15 cm. At the pre-treating stage, 3 ml liquidwas fetched and then centrifugation at 10000 r min−1 to obtain the solid powder. Tracking the programperiodically while maintainingUV light. The dye concentrationwas determined throughUV-vis spectrophotometry. Since the relationship between dye concentration and absorbancewas linear, the degradation efficiencywas calculated using the formula as follows.
*h = -⎜ ⎟ ⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠ C co 1 100%
where η: degradation efficiency; C: dye concentration after a certain time; Co: original dye concentration. In order to judge the relationship between catalytic effect and initial concentration, the concentrations of 10 mg l−1, 20 mg l−1, 30 mg l−1, 40 mg l−1 and 50 mg l−1 were chosen. The catalyst retrievability and reutilizationwas an indicator for its performance. In this experiment, we characterized the property through five cycles. The testingwas handled at a concentration of 30 mg l−1 for different dye solutions and sustained 5 h. After each cycle, washing samples three timeswith deionizedwater and ethanol, centrifuging and drying to be recycled.

sections.heading: 3.1. Catalyst characteristics
sections.text:
Hydrothermal synthesis of TiO2 nanowires and nanoparticles with TBT andHAuCl4 as the precursor. The surfacemorphology of the samples was observed by TEMand shown infigure 1. Figures 1(a) and (c)were corresponding to pure nanoparticles and nanowires, respectively. Asfigure 1(a) shows nanowire with smooth, flat surface, no defects and high aspect ratio. Figure 1(c) shows the size of nano particles was smaller than 20 nm and not a regular circle. Figure 1(b)was TEM image of AuNPS@TiO2NWS. Au nanoparticles were evenly distributed in nanowires. Fromfigure 1(d) displayed, the dark points were Au particles and the sizewas less than 10 nm. In conclude, Au particles were successfully and uniform loaded onTiO2materials. However, owing to
the aggregation of TiO2NPS, in the characterization of TEM,Au particles were uneven distributed compared to nanowires.
In order to distinguish crystallographic formof nanoparticles, XRD analysis were carried out and the result was shown infigure 2. Figure 2 depicts line (a) correspond toAu@TiO2 and line (b) of pure TiO2. Pure TiO2 samples were anatase crystal structure which had (101), (004), (200), (105), (211) and (204) lattice planes in order. Thesewas index from standard color card (JCPDS file#: 021-1272) [57].
Most were coincidingwith pure TiO2, and a fewdifferent wasmarked in red five-point star. The (111), (200), (220) and (311) lattice planes belonged toAu [59]. This indicating that gold particles were got through
hydrothermal reaction and had a good scattered in catalyst. The lattice planes (103), (004) and (112)was not found ascribed the lattices near to TiO2 lattices which overlapped each other. In addition, whole crystal shapes of diffraction peakswere distinct and sharp, exhibiting integrity crystal structure ofmaterials.
In this article, themass rate of Au3+ to Ti4+was determined to 0.5%, 1%, 2% and 5%, respectively. The ability of catalytic activity was discussed through photocatalyticMethylene blue. Degradation effect of Methylene blue (30 mg l−1) containing catalyst under ultraviolet light for 5 hwas shown infigure 3(a).
In order to getmore accurate data, the degradation experiment repeated five times, then the average values were used to represent themeasured amount, and the error bars were used to characterize the distribution of the data, where the height of the error bars were±standard deviation.
The photodegradation efficiencywas increased as following order: neat TiO2<AuNPS@TiO2NPS (0.5at% Au)<AuNPS@TiO2NPS (1at%Au)<AuNPS@TiO2NPS (2at%Au)<AuNPS@TiO2NPS (5at%Au). This phenomenonwas also applicable to the degradation of the AuNPS@TiO2NWS asfigure 3(b). Due to the rapid transfer of electrons, the degradation efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NWS (5at%Au)was a dramatic increase.When Aunanoparticles were incorporated, the impurity levels ofmetal appeared in the forbidden band [60]. As ultraviolet light was applied to the doping system, these impurity levels accepted excited electrons in the valence band, the recombination of electrons and holes was reduced [61]. On the contrary, the recombination of holes impaired the utilization of photogenerated electrons [62–64].
Studies have shown that the photodegradation process ofMethylene blue conforms to themodel of Langmuir–Hinshelwood first-order reaction kinetics. Therefore, the reaction rate constant could be obtained by calculation through the following equation:
*=⎜ ⎟ ⎛ ⎝ ⎞ ⎠In C C k t0
While k and t express the rate constant (min−1) of photocatalytic degradation and theMethylene blue irradiation time (min), respectively. C0was the concentration ofMethylene blue after adsorption equilibrium andCwas Methylene blue concentration during reaction time. Figure 3(b) proposes the linearfit of the photocatalytic degradation time against ln (C0/C). It was noteworthy finding that AuNPS@TiO2NPS (5at%Au) reaction rate was exceed twenty times than pure nanoTiO2 particles. Nearly 80%ofMethylene bluewas degraded since exposure toUV-light for 30 min as figure 3(c)displayed.
Figure 4was a schematic diagram for the electronic transmission path route of AuNPS@TiO2NPS and AuNPS@TiO2NWS. The reasonswhyAuNPS@TiO2NWS exhibited high catalytic activity were as follows. (1): the catalytic efficiencywas determined by a competition between the charge transfer to the surface of the photocatalyst (for reaction) and recombination. As for nanowires, the electron transmission pathwas longer than particles. Thus, the probability of electron and hole recombinationwas reduced, and the utilization rate of electronwas improved obviously. (2): anatase TiO2 crystals with exposed high-energy (001) facets processed high photocatalytic activity.With this inmind, it was envisaged that TiO2 containing such facets. Because of a hierarchical structure and high-energy (001) facets, AuNPS@TiO2NWS revealedmarkedly promoted levels of photocatalytic activity.
Figure 5was the contrast of final dyes degradation capacity with different concentrations after 5 h underUV irradiations. The dyes selected included acid dye (azophloxine) and basic dye (Rhodamine B). As can be seen from the figure 5, the degradation efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NWSwas increasedwith azophloxine initial concentration increased.When the initial concentration exceeds 30 mg L−1, the degradation efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NWS onRhodamine Bwas saturated aswell as AuNPS@TiO2NPS performed. Furthermore, AuNPS@TiO2NWS had a linear growth process in degradation capacity of azophloxinewhile the amount of AuNPS@TiO2NPS for azophloxine degradation capacity was tend to be gentle when the initial concentration up to 40 mg l−1. Nevertheless, for Rhodamine B dyes, the degradation efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NPSwas better than AuNPS@TiO2NWS. This indicates that the amount of degradation capacity was not proportional to the initial concentration.
With regard to azophloxine dyes, it was clearly that AuNPS@TiO2NWSwith an impressive degradation efficiency than that of AuNPS@TiO2NPS. Based on the test of the electric potential of samples, the AuNPS@TiO2NWSwere negatively chargedwhile AuNPS@TiO2NPSwere positively charged. The potential of Rhodamine B dyewas negative in the aqueous solution.On the account of heteronuclear cells were attracted to each other, the adsorption amountwas increased, leading degrading amount climbed. Similar to the same kind of electron core repelledwhichwas not conducive to adsorption. This was the reasonwhy the catalysis of AuNPS@TiO2NPS for Rhodamine Bwas outstanding.However, accompanied by the dye concentration aggrandized, the reaction site was excessively occupied, which limits the reaction rate.
In order to enhancing the catalytic ability, all samples were subjected to calcination under the protection of Ar. The surfacemorphology of calcined samplewas characterized by SEMandTEM.The nanowirewhichwas calcined at 800 °Cwas shown infigure 6(c). The previous high aspect ratio structure of nanowires was disappearedwhile the defect and fracturedwere explicitly occurred.However, AuNPS@TiO2NPS did not change. Notably, gold particles agglomerated and turned larger in size after calcination.
The calcination temperature was set to 200 °C, 400 °C, 600 °C and 800 °Cunder the protection of Ar and roasted for 3 h. Figure 7 expressed that the intensity of characteristic crystalline surface of anatase (101)was distinct and pointed after calcine. Fromoriginal samples to calcinated in 600 °C, lines exhibited a sharpness peak at 25.27°. It indicated calcining generated the crystallinity raisedwithin tolerable temperature range.When the calcination temperature was heighten to 800 °C, the XRDpattern emerged rutile peaks as the catalyst crystal form transformationwere observed during calcination [65]. The (004) peakswas shifted after calcinated in 600 °C indicated a tendency of crystal transformation.
Under hot circumstance, the atoms of anatase rearranged to produce rutile crystal forms. The anatase structure existed as ametastable structure throughout the phase transition, and the phase transition from anatase to rutile was an irreversible process. Nevertheless, the specific phase transition temperature of anatase samples vary somewhat depending on the preparation conditions [66, 67]. The difference of anatase and rutile in crystal formwas the degree of distortion and connection of the octahedral structure [68]. Although the anatase
structure has no good stability of the rutile, it waswidely used in practice because the anatase phase exhibited excellent photocatalysis and sensitization characteristics [69–71].
For the sake of comparing the effects of time on the catalytic efficiency of different calcination temperatures, the calcined samples were subjected to photocatalytic experiments.Methylene blue dyewith a concentration of 30 mg l−1 was tested under ultraviolet light. And before ultraviolet irradiation, dilute dye solutionwas stirred in the dark for the first 30 min to achieve the suction and desorption equilibrium. Figure 8(a)was a degradation diagramof AuNPS@TiO2NPS, and thefigure 8(c)was a degradationmap of AuNPS@TiO2NWS, respectively. Figure 8(b)wasMethylene blue photocatalytic degradation kinetic fit of the AuNPS@TiO2NPS, whilefigure 8(d) wasAuNPS@TiO2NWS.
It could be observed that as the catalytic time increased, the catalytic efficiencywas significantly improved. The sample calcined at 600 °Cgainedmaximumdegradation onmethylene blue, the final degradation rate of AuNPS@TiO2NPS reached 99.8%while AuNPS@TiO2NWSwas 96.8%. Forfigure 8(a), the degradation efficiency fastly increasedwithin the beginning 90 min after thermal treatment at the temperature under 600 °C and 800 °C. Then degradation rate increased slowlywith the time going on. This phenomenonwas discrepant for AuNPS@TiO2NWS. As exhibited infigure 8(b), all samples approached the degradation saturation in 60 min Therefore, calcination could significantly improve the degradation efficiency, and calcination at 600 °C performed best. In addition, the amount of adsorption increased under dark conditions after burning process. The larger adsorption amount accompanied by the higher degradation efficiency. It was worth thewhile that the amount of adsorption of the nanowires was always higher than that of the nanoparticles.
According to the solid electron band theory, the energy band of a semiconductormaterial was discontinuous, and its band structure was composed of a valence band formed by low-energy electrons and a conduction band formed by excited high-energy electrons. The imparity in energy between the top and the conduction bandwas called the band gap. It was reported that the forbidden band of the anatase was 3.2 ev, while rutile was 3.0 ev [51, 66]. Catalytic efficiencywas affected by two points whichwere the absorption range of visible light and the recombination velocity of hole electrons [72]. In this experiment, the light sourcewas ultraviolet light with awavelength of 254 nm. Therefore the catalytic efficiencywas affected by the recombination velocity of hole electrons. According to the XRD test results, at the calcination temperature of 200 °C, 400 °C, 600 °C, samples were anatase type, indicating that the calcinationmakes the crystal structure more complete and promoted catalytic efficiency effect. Furthermore, high temperature calcination could remove less unremoved cl in the previous hydrothermal reactionwhichwould impair degradation efficiency [73]. However, at 800 °C, the rutile phase appeared. Smaller band gaps lead to an increase in the recombination rate of photogenerated electron holes in thematerial, further reduced photocatalytic activity to some extent [74]. This why the calcination temperature rises to 800 °Cbut the catalytic efficiency decreases.
The effect of calcination temperature on reaction rate (k) ofMethylene blue dyewas displayed infigures 8(b) and (d). After calcination at high temperatures, bothAuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS improved the catalytic properties. However, the increase of AuNPS@TiO2NPSmaterials was not prominent.When the temperature reached to 800 °C, the catalytic efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NWSwas declineed. Opposed to
AuNPS@TiO2NPSwhichwas slightly degraded by the calcined sample at 600 °C. Therewere discrepant results possibility due to several reasons. Reason 1: the catalytic efficiency of the uncalcinedwirewas 85.9%, that value implies an outstanding catalytic ability. Because AuNPS@TiO2NWSwith awell-formed crystallinity was generated after 24 h of hydrothermal reaction. The increasing in crystallinity by thermal treatment was not noticeable. AuNPS@TiO2NPS undergo 8 h of hydrothermal reaction, and the crystal formhad a significant improvement via high temperature process. Reason 2: at extremely high temperatures (800 °C), as the crystal phase changed, the structure of thewire would broke. The change of surfacemicrotopography resulted inweaker nanowires structural such as higher specific surface area and faster speed of electron transport. Thus, the catalytic efficiency of the samplewas lower than the ordinary. In contrast, relatively stablemorphology of nano particles ensured AuNPS@TiO2NPS had high catalytic efficiency.
In order to investigate the reusability of AuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS, a variety of dyes were used to test the recyclability of AuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS. The detailed datawas corresponding to figures 9(a) and (b). The diagram shown the relationship between the degradation efficiency of AuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS and the number of cycles. Overall, as the number of uses increased, the degradation efficiency decreased. Among them, the first three reductions were obviously and then the degradation rate was flat. But for thefifth time, the degradation rate of AuNPS@TiO2NPS could still bemaintained at 87.25% for Methylene blue, 81.65% for Rhodamine B and 79.70% for Azophloxine. As for AuNPS@TiO2NWS, the degradation ratewas still above 75% for all dyes. The decreased of degradation efficiencywas attributed to the lossmass in the centrifugal process. Thus, it demonstratedAuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWSwere benign and renewable degradationmaterial.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
This experiment used one-stepmethod to prepare AuNPS@TiO2NPS, and sample has good catalytic efficiency. The prepared samples were compared toAuNPS@TiO2NWS. The degradation capacity of AuNPS@TiO2NPS and AuNPS@TiO2NWSwas different for different dyes. However, AuNPS@TiO2NWS performed better. The sample was calcined under different temperatures. And the catalytic performance of the AuNPS@TiO2NPSwas significantly improvedwhile AuNPS@TiO2NWS decreased. Furthermore, the rutile crystal appeared after 800 °Ccalcination.
Figure 8.The kineticfit of the AuNPS@TiO2NWSwith time: (a)Time effective on the degradation efficiency ofMethylene blue dye under different calcination temperature AuNPS@TiO2NPS; (b)The kinetic fit of the AuNPS@TiO2NPS with time (c)Time effective on the degradation efficiency ofMethylene blue dyewith different calcination temperature AuNPS@TiO2NWS; (d)The kineticfit of the AuNPS@TiO2NWSwith time.
TheAuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS performedwell in catalytic acidic dye and basic dye. Afterfive times of use, they have a good catalytic effect, indicating that it can be reusedwithout secondary pollution.

sections.text:

metadata.abstractText: In this experiment, gold loadedTiO2 nanoparticles (AuNPS@TiO2NPS) and nanowires (AuNPS@TiO2NWS)were successfully prepared through one step hydrothermal reaction. The photocatalytic experimental results showed that the catalytic efficiency of Au loadedTiO2 increases with the increase of Au ratio.When the gold contentwas 5%, bothAuNPS@TiO2NPS and AuNPS@TiO2NWS performedwell in catalysisMethylene blue. It was also clear that AuNPS@TiO2NWS performed better than that of AuNPS@TiO2NPS. After calcination at 800 °C for 3 h under the protection of Ar, the crystal phase of both samples shifted to rutile. Furthermore, fromSEMandTEM image, the linear structurewas destroyed under high temperature which decreased the catalytic efficiency. It indicated that the crystal phasewas strengthened and the catalytic effect was improved obviously by calcinations. By comparing the catalytic efficiencies of dyes with different initial concentrations after 5 h underUV irradiation, the time and content at which the AuNPS@TiO2NPS andAuNPS@TiO2NWS reached degradation saturationwere related to the potential of catalyst surface. After five times of repeated use, the degradation rate could still be 87.25% forMethylene blue, 81.65% for Rhodamine B and 79.70% for Azophloxine. The results would indicate that the samples as prepared had good recycling performance.
